results.title: Paradise of adventurers
results.creator_credit: Gwyneth Hughes, Yorkshire Television and Granite Productions
results.brief_description:
Episode number 1 of Series “China Rising”.
A two part program that details the history of China in tumultuous stages of its history from the 1920s through to the 1940s, seen through the eyes of the people living in Shanghai. Part one opens with Shanghai in the 1920s, a centre of foreign trade and colonialist occupation by the English and Japanese, disjointed rule of the country at the hands of warlords and the beginning of a concerted Nationalist and unification movement under the direction of Chiang Kai-Shek. The program discusses Chiang Kai-Shek and his KMT troops as they battled and defeated the warlords across China to unify the country under a Nationalist flag and outlines the growing opposition to foreign ownership and occupation and a reign of terror against them that also included those who had been made wealthy from foreign trade and saw an influx of these people to the International settlement in the relative safety of Shang-hai. The explosive Nationalist atmosphere of the time is also depicted through coverage of the “White Terror” which resulted in the execution of thousands of suspected communists in the country as the definitive drive for national unification increased. Part two discusses Shanghai under Nationalist rule where the left movement still thrived but under careful auspices of representing Nationalist ideals and where the strength of Japan as a ruler over China’s economy became ever more pointed in the puppet government of the Last Emperor and the Japanese invasion of Shang-hai in 1932. The program then outlines the subsequent humiliation of a truce with Japan and the rise to power in Northern China of the powerful son of a warlord that aligned himself with Chiang Kai-Shek and heightened the Nationalist’s campaigning and instigated an attempt to oust Japan which eventually consumed the country in a 12 year war with Japan which failed for the Nationalists but became a foundation for a rising tide of Communism. This comphrehensive documentary uses rare archival footage, interviews with the chinese and ex-patriot people of the time and coverage of the impact of this stage in China’s history on contemporary China and Taiwan to tell the story of this complex period of 20th century Chinese history. Includes Teachers notes.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Gwyneth Hughes, Yorkshire Television and Granite Productions

results.title: Passing out
results.creator_credit: Simon Target and Australian Broadcasting Corporation
results.brief_description:
Episode number 5 of Series “The Academy”.
The third year cadets are graduating and the rehearsal is a test to many as standing out in sweltering heat for an hour sees many of them fainting. Kizzy will find out the outcome of her proposal to the Commandant to let her graduate, despite her injury, and attend the Graduation Ball which they are all looking forward to after three years of discipline and hard work.

results.title: No pain, no mess
results.creator_credit: Simon Target and Australian Broadcasting Corporation
results.brief_description:
Episode number 4 of Series “The Academy”.
Six weeks into their training and its getting tough for some. Laura is having problems sleeping and trying to survive on four hours sleep a night. The cadets are coming up to their first parade and also their first visit with friends and family since joining ADFA. The third year cadets are on a tour of Gallipoli where they come to terms with the reality of war and loss of life, they also participate in the annual soccer match against Turkey; a match Australia has never won.

results.title: Bedtimes over
results.creator_credit: Simon Target and Australian Broadcasting Corporation
results.brief_description:
Episode number 3 of Series “The Academy”.
Bedtime’s over: the second year cadets get a chance to put their training to the test when they are sent out on exercise to Puckapunyal, to go over the area and determine whether anyone they may come across is Militia or friend. The Navy cadets board HMAS Tobruk for their first trip and we are privy to their experience of what life is really like at sea and how it differs from their expectations.

results.title: Killing ground
results.creator_credit: Simon Target and Australian Broadcasting Corporation
results.brief_description:
Episode number 2 of Series “The Academy”.
The Killing ground looks at the physical and moral challenges in training the cadets. The cadets are starting to come to terms with the reality of the fitness training they are undertaking, training which comes before any academic study. This episode also focuses on how the female cadets are adjusting to a predominately male facility. Two girls, terrified of heights, are put to the test on an exercise to bring them to face to face with their fear. Kizzy reveals that because she has injured her foot in training and has no arch left in her left foot she may not be able to graduate. After spending three years at the academy - she may be discharged as physically unfit.

results.title: Everyone's full bottle now
results.creator_credit: Simon Target and Australian Broadcasting Corporation
results.brief_description:
Episode number 1 of Series “The Academy”.
The Academy looks at life as a new cadet at ADFA - the Australian Defence Force Academy in Canberra. “Full bottle now” introduces Ilana Napier, a new cadet who leaves her family and home to spend three years training at ADFA and the struggles and challenges she experiences. This is also an important time at ADFA because they are undertaking a new experiment with training whereby new cadets will be trained by staff instead of by third year cadets. Kizzy Hyde shares her experiences and takes the viewer on a tour of the barracks as a third year cadet.

results.title: Peach's gold
results.brief_description: Bill Peach describes how the discovery of gold changed the course of Australia’s history. Through dramatised re-enactments and historical footage, the effects of the new economic force on population, the location of towns, wealth generation, the development of transport networks and the introduction of a representative democracy are all investigated. In this series Bill Peach traces the story of gold from its earliest discovery to the early 1980s.
results.description: Bill Peach describes how the discovery of gold changed the course of Australia’s history. Through dramatised re-enactments and historical footage, the effects of the new economic force on population, the location of towns, wealth generation, the development of transport networks and the introduction of a representative democracy are all investigated. In this series Bill Peach traces the story of gold from its earliest discovery to the early 1980s.

In this series Bill Peach traces the story of gold from its earliest discovery to the early 1980s.
results.media_note: Sorry, we don't have images or video for this item.

results.title: Life on the goldfields
results.brief_description:
Episode number 3 of Series “Peach’s gold”.
Bill Peach presents a look at life on the goldfields after the Eureka stockade. It was a colourful but often violent time, where fortunes were made and lost in a heartbeat. Using dramatised re-enactments as well as historical footage, the point is made that not all of those who came to the goldfields were fortunate enough to realise their dream, however they almost always embodied the pioneer spirit. Out of this free-wheeling era emerged the beginnings of a new society.

results.title: Land of gold
results.brief_description:
Episode number 5 of Series “Peach’s gold”.
Using dramatised re-enactments as well as historical footage, Bill Peach investigates the economic crash of the 1890s and the exhaustion of the goldfields at Ballarat and Bendigo. He describes how the less well known but far more productive goldfields at Coolgardie and Kalgoorlie rescued Australia from the depths of depression and continued to contribute to the country’s economy up to the early 1980s.
